signalslink:block-handbooktext-blocksens:
The Block Sensor detects the presence of a block at a selected adjacent position and, based on its type (and optionally an input signal), provides output information about its state or slot fill level.
Currently supported blocks are:
Anvil - if there is a sufficiently hot ingot on the anvil for forging, the Output signal is 1. Otherwise it outputs signal 0.
Doors, gates, trapdoors - For doors and gates you need to monitor the ground-level block on the hinge side. If the block is open, the Output signal is 1; if it is closed, the Output signal is 0.
Chest or generally a container or any blocks that have inventory slots (e.g. firepit, barrel, trough, etc.). The Output signal depends on the input signal.
The input signal determines which slot is to be scanned.
Signal 1-14 selects slots 0-13. The output is information about how full the slot is relative to the maximum stack capacity of the item in that slot, converted to a 0-15 signal.
Signal 15 indicates that the sensor should detect the overall fill level of all slots, e.g. the entire chest.
Some other block not listed above - If there is nothing in the monitored space (air), the Output signal is 0. If there is water, the output is 2 for fresh water or 3 for salt water. If there is any other block, the Output signal is 1.
signalslink:block-handbooktext-entitysen:
The Entity Sensor detects the presence of entities (players, animals, wild animals, or monsters) in the marked area and can provide information on its outputs about their count, type, or state. The sensor requires one or more Temporal gears to be charged to operate. The consumption rate depends on the size of the monitored area.
Inputs x, y, z determine the size of the monitored area in blocks.
On the Error output there is signal 1 if the sensor is discharged, otherwise 0.
Inputs Output 1 setting and Output 2 setting determine what information will be provided on outputs 1 and 2. You can thus get different information on each output based on these input settings.
Options are:
1 - Output returns Count. The number of detected entities.
2 - Output returns Category. Bit flags for entity categories 0–3: player, creature, animal, wild animal.
3 - Output returns Life state. All detected entities are: 1–dead, 2–alive, or 15–mixed.
4 - Output returns Sex. All detected entities are: 1–male, 2–female, or 15–mixed.
5 - Output returns Age. All detected entities are: 1–young, 2–adult, or 15–mixed.
6 - Output returns Species. All detected entities are: 1–player, 2–animal, 3–wild animal, 4–creature, or 15–mixed.
7 - Output returns Reproductive state. All detected entities are: 1–ready to mate, 2–pregnant, 3–lactating, or 15–mixed.
8 - Output returns Reproductive state flags. Bit flags 0–2: ready to mate, pregnant, lactating.
9 - Output returns Minimum generation. The minimum detected generation is: 0–15. Entities without a specified generation are ignored.
10 - Output returns Maximum generation. The maximum detected generation is: 0–15. Entities without a specified generation are ignored.
11 - Output returns Minimum weight. The minimum detected weight is: 1–starving, 2–low, 3–decent, 4–good. Entities without a specified weight (not animals) are ignored.
12 - Output returns Maximum weight. The maximum detected weight is: 1–starving, 2–low, 3–decent, 4–good. Entities without a specified weight (not animals) are ignored.
signalslink:block-handbooktext-managedch: A Managed Chute enables automated transport of items between different blocks.
signalslink:block-handbooktext-managedwa: A Managed Chute embedded in a wall enables automated transport of items between different blocks. It allows transporting items through walls, which can be very useful for hidden transport systems or for moving items from a cellar or into a cellar without disturbing the cool cellar environment, important for long-term food preservation.
signalslink:usageinfo-signalslink-text:
SignalsLink
Extends the Signals mod with additional components.

To monitor a nearby block you can use the Block Sensor.
If you need to monitor your herd of livestock, the Entity Sensor is great for that.
If you want to automate some tasks, the Managed Chute will serve you well; it can transport items between blocks similarly to a chute, but you control it with signals and it gives you much greater control over what is transported. Its variant Managed Chute built into a wall then allows transporting items through walls, which can be very useful for hidden transport systems or for moving items from a cellar or into a cellar without disturbing the cool cellar environment, important for long-term food preservation.
signalslink:usageinfo-paperconditions-te:
Some blocks from the SignalsLink mod allow using paper conditions:
• Block Sensor
• Managed Chute
• Managed Chute Built into a Wall
Paper conditionspaper conditions are conditions written on parchment. These conditions can be used to influence a block's behavior, for example to control output signals or to filter items in chutes.
Conditions are written into blocks (paragraphs). Each block consists of one or more lines, where each line contains one condition. All conditions in one block are evaluated by applying the logical AND operator between them, and the result yields the final value of the whole block.
Individual blocks are separated by an empty line. The logical OR operator is then applied to the resulting values of the individual blocks. Evaluation of individual conditions within a block proceeds from top to bottom, as the conditions are written on the paper. Evaluation of blocks also proceeds in the order in which the blocks are written on the paper. This means that as soon as a block evaluates to true, this result is returned to the calling block and evaluation does not continue with the next block. This is very important and you must take it into account.

We distinguish several types of conditions:
game:plank-oak - Evaluates whether the observed item in the inventory or the observed block is of the specified type, i.e., its code matches exactly the specified code. If yes, the condition returns true.
game:plank-* - Evaluates whether the observed item or block is of the specified type in any of its variants (denoted by the asterisk). If yes, the condition returns true.
@.*-plank-.* - The code of the observed item or block is evaluated using this regular expression. If it matches, the condition returns true.
attribute > 1 - Evaluates the value of an item attribute in the inventory or of the observed block. Various comparison operators can be used here (greater/less/equal). After evaluation, the result of the comparison is returned (true/false).
attribute - If only the name of an item attribute is given in the condition, it evaluates whether it has a value or not. That is, zero, NULL, an empty string, or false evaluates as false. A non-zero value, a string, or true evaluates as true.

The negation operator ! can be applied to all conditions. For example, !game:plank-oak evaluates to true if the observed item or block is not exactly oak planks.
At the end of each block, you can add an instruction to set the output signal, for example output 1, which specifies that if this block evaluates to true, signal 1 will be sent to the output. This only matters for the Block Sensor block, which allows you to set which signal will be sent to the output if a block or item matches the conditions listed in the block. For other blocks that allow using paper conditions, this instruction is ignored.Setting up conditionsWrite the conditions on parchment. Do not sign the parchment so you can edit the text again.
Transfer the conditions into a block that supports it by right-clicking the given block with this parchment. The conditions will be saved into the block and you will see them in the info window when you look at the block.
To remove the conditions from a block, take an empty parchment into your hand, sneak (shift key) and click the given block with this empty parchment. This will erase the conditions from the block.
If you want to copy the conditions from a block onto an empty parchment, right-click the given block with an empty parchment without sneaking.
And finally, a tip to find out what code a block or item has and what attributes you have available for use in conditional expressions:
Take the item you are interested in into your hand, hold the ctrl key and right-click a block that supports paper conditions with this block. The item's code and its attributes available for paper conditions will be saved into that block. You can now copy them onto a blank parchment as described above, and edit them as you like into condition blocks and use them to configure the block.
